member.name: T:QRScanner.controller.ScannerController
member.summary: Handles interactions with Zebra scanners via the CoreScanner SDK.

remarks.para: The class provides methods to manage scanner devices, including opening and closing the CoreScanner API, detecting scanners, selecting a scanner, and performing operations such as enabling/disabling scans, rebooting, triggering LEDs, and beeping the scanner.
The class supports multiple scanners, allowing operations on all detected devices or a specific selected scanner. Events related to barcode scanning are also handled and propagated to subscribers.

The class enforces validations to ensure a scanner is selected before performing specific operations. It also wraps SDK commands in a structured way, providing detailed results using and throwing meaningful exceptions when errors occur.

member.summary: Serves as the base class for all custom exceptions in the QRScanner namespace.

remarks.para: The class provides a foundation for exceptions that occur in the QRScanner system. It extends the standard class and includes additional context by associating a object.

The property provides detailed information about the command that triggered the exception, such as its execution status, any XML output, and relevant messages. This allows for better debugging and diagnostic capabilities when handling scanner-related errors.

Derived exceptions should call one of the provided constructors to initialize the message and associate the relevant object. Additionally, an optional inner exception can be passed to maintain the exception chain.

Use this class when handling responses from the CoreScanner SDK to provide detailed insights into command outcomes, particularly for debugging and diagnostics purposes.

member.name: T:QRScanner.service.QRScannerService
member.summary: Manages the lifecycle, diagnostics, and scanning operations for Zebra scanners.

remarks.para: The class serves as a high-level service to control scanner devices, leveraging the to interact with the CoreScanner SDK. It provides methods for starting and stopping the scanning process, running diagnostics, and handling events when a barcode or QR code is scanned.

The class follows the Singleton design pattern, ensuring a single shared instance of the service. It incorporates event-driven programming by exposing the event, which propagates decoded QR or barcode data to external subscribers.

To ensure proper operation, a successful diagnostics check must be performed before starting the scanning process. Diagnostics verify that the CoreScanner API can be opened, scanners can be detected and selected, and essential settings (such as disabling scans and LEDs) can be applied.

The scanning process runs asynchronously in a background task, allowing cancellation and graceful shutdown using a cancellation token. The service logs all operations for transparency and debugging purposes.

member.name: T:QRScanner.utility.QRScannerLogger
member.summary: Provides logging functionality for the QR Scanner application.

remarks.para: The class implements a singleton pattern to ensure a single instance of the logger is used throughout the application. It logs messages at different levels (INFO, WARNING, ERROR) and appends them both to an in-memory queue and a persistent log file.

The logger maintains a counter for log entries and ensures all logs include a timestamp, log level, and unique log index. Logs are saved in the "out" directory under the project root and can be retrieved or cleared programmatically.

member.name: T:QRScanner.view.MainForm
member.summary: Represents the main graphical user interface (GUI) for managing and interacting with the QR scanner service.

remarks.para: The class serves as the entry point for the QR scanner application, providing the user interface for diagnostics, starting/stopping scanning services, selecting scanners, and viewing logs.

This class also handles event subscriptions for the QR code scanning process, ensuring the main thread interacts seamlessly with the scanner service running in the background. Thread-safe methods are implemented to update the UI elements asynchronously when events are triggered.

Key functionalities include:
Performing diagnostics to detect available scanners.
Starting and stopping the scanning service with background event handling.
Updating logs and scanner details on the interface.
Handling user inputs, such as selecting a scanner by ID and triggering beeps.
